message: Data is being piped into `bash` from a `curl` command. An attacker with control of the server in the `curl` command could inject malicious code into the pipe, resulting in a system compromise. Avoid piping untrusted data into `bash` or any other shell if you can. If you must do this, consider checking the SHA sum of the content returned by the server to verify its integrity.
cwe: CWE-95: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Dynamically Evaluated Code ('Eval Injection')
cweId: CWE-95: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Dynamically Evaluated Code ('Eval Injection')

message: Detected string concatenation with a non-literal variable in a util.format / console.log function. If an attacker injects a format specifier in the string, it will forge the log message. Try to use constant values for the format string.
cwe: CWE-134: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String
cweId: CWE-134: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String

message: By not specifying a USER, a program in the container may run as 'root'. This is a security hazard. If an attacker can control a process running as root, they may have control over the container. Ensure that the last USER in a Dockerfile is a USER other than 'root'.
cwe: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management
cweId: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management

message: Using variable interpolation `${{...}}` with `github` context data in a `run:` step could allow an attacker to inject their own code into the runner. This would allow them to steal secrets and code. `github` context data can have arbitrary user input and should be treated as untrusted. Instead, use an intermediate environment variable with `env:` to store the data and use the environment variable in the `run:` script. Be sure to use double-quotes the environment variable, like this: "$ENVVAR".
cwe: CWE-78: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')
cweId: CWE-78: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

message: Found '$SPAWN' with '{shell: true}'. This is dangerous because this call will spawn the command using a shell process. Doing so propagates current shell settings and variables, which makes it much easier for a malicious actor to execute commands. Use '{shell: false}' instead.

message: RegExp() called with a `examplePath` function argument, this might allow an attacker to cause a Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) within your application as RegExP blocks the main thread. For this reason, it is recommended to use hardcoded regexes instead. If your regex is run on user-controlled input, consider performing input validation or use a regex checking/sanitization library such as https://www.npmjs.com/package/recheck to verify that the regex does not appear vulnerable to ReDoS.

message: RegExp() called with a `urlReg` function argument, this might allow an attacker to cause a Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) within your application as RegExP blocks the main thread. For this reason, it is recommended to use hardcoded regexes instead. If your regex is run on user-controlled input, consider performing input validation or use a regex checking/sanitization library such as https://www.npmjs.com/package/recheck to verify that the regex does not appear vulnerable to ReDoS.

message: Possibility of prototype polluting function detected. By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the software depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as hasOwnProperty, toString or valueOf). Possible mitigations might be: freezing the object prototype, using an object without prototypes (via Object.create(null) ), blocking modifications of attributes that resolve to object prototype, using Map instead of object.
cwe: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
cweId: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

message: Possibility of prototype polluting function detected. By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the software depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as hasOwnProperty, toString or valueOf). Possible mitigations might be: freezing the object prototype, using an object without prototypes (via Object.create(null) ), blocking modifications of attributes that resolve to object prototype, using Map instead of object.
cwe: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
cweId: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

message: RegExp() called with a `e` function argument, this might allow an attacker to cause a Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) within your application as RegExP blocks the main thread. For this reason, it is recommended to use hardcoded regexes instead. If your regex is run on user-controlled input, consider performing input validation or use a regex checking/sanitization library such as https://www.npmjs.com/package/recheck to verify that the regex does not appear vulnerable to ReDoS.
cwe: CWE-1333: Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity
cweId: CWE-1333: Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity

message: Possibility of prototype polluting function detected. By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the software depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as hasOwnProperty, toString or valueOf). Possible mitigations might be: freezing the object prototype, using an object without prototypes (via Object.create(null) ), blocking modifications of attributes that resolve to object prototype, using Map instead of object.
cwe: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
cweId: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

message: Possibility of prototype polluting function detected. By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the software depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as hasOwnProperty, toString or valueOf). Possible mitigations might be: freezing the object prototype, using an object without prototypes (via Object.create(null) ), blocking modifications of attributes that resolve to object prototype, using Map instead of object.
cwe: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
cweId: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

message: Detected string concatenation with a non-literal variable in a util.format / console.log function. If an attacker injects a format specifier in the string, it will forge the log message. Try to use constant values for the format string.
cwe: CWE-134: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String
cweId: CWE-134: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String

message: Possibility of prototype polluting function detected. By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the software depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as hasOwnProperty, toString or valueOf). Possible mitigations might be: freezing the object prototype, using an object without prototypes (via Object.create(null) ), blocking modifications of attributes that resolve to object prototype, using Map instead of object.
cwe: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
cweId: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

Possible mitigations might be: freezing the object prototype, using an object without prototypes (via Object.create(null) ), blocking modifications of attributes that resolve to object prototype, using Map instead of object.
cwe: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
cweId: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

message: RegExp() called with a `r` function argument, this might allow an attacker to cause a Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) within your application as RegExP blocks the main thread. For this reason, it is recommended to use hardcoded regexes instead. If your regex is run on user-controlled input, consider performing input validation or use a regex checking/sanitization library such as https://www.npmjs.com/package/recheck to verify that the regex does not appear vulnerable to ReDoS.

message: RegExp() called with a `routes` function argument, this might allow an attacker to cause a Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) within your application as RegExP blocks the main thread. For this reason, it is recommended to use hardcoded regexes instead. If your regex is run on user-controlled input, consider performing input validation or use a regex checking/sanitization library such as https://www.npmjs.com/package/recheck to verify that the regex does not appear vulnerable to ReDoS.
cwe: CWE-1333: Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity
cweId: CWE-1333: Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity

message: Possibility of prototype polluting function detected. By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the software depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as hasOwnProperty, toString or valueOf). Possible mitigations might be: freezing the object prototype, using an object without prototypes (via Object.create(null) ), blocking modifications of attributes that resolve to object prototype, using Map instead of object.
cwe: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
cweId: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

message: RegExp() called with a `obj` function argument, this might allow an attacker to cause a Regular Expression Denial-of-Service (ReDoS) within your application as RegExP blocks the main thread. For this reason, it is recommended to use hardcoded regexes instead. If your regex is run on user-controlled input, consider performing input validation or use a regex checking/sanitization library such as https://www.npmjs.com/package/recheck to verify that the regex does not appear vulnerable to ReDoS.
cwe: CWE-1333: Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity
cweId: CWE-1333: Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity

message: The call to 'createDecipheriv' with the Galois Counter Mode (GCM) mode of operation is missing an expected authentication tag length. If the expected authentication tag length is not specified or otherwise checked, the application might be tricked into verifying a shorter-than-expected authentication tag. This can be abused by an attacker to spoof ciphertexts or recover the implicit authentication key of GCM, allowing arbitrary forgeries.

message: Possibility of prototype polluting function detected. By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the software depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as hasOwnProperty, toString or valueOf). Possible mitigations might be: freezing the object prototype, using an object without prototypes (via Object.create(null) ), blocking modifications of attributes that resolve to object prototype, using Map instead of object.
cwe: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes
cweId: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

message: Detected the use of eval(). eval() can be dangerous if used to evaluate dynamic content. If this content can be input from outside the program, this may be a code injection vulnerability. Ensure evaluated content is not definable by external sources.
cwe: CWE-95: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Dynamically Evaluated Code ('Eval Injection')

message: Detected string concatenation with a non-literal variable in a util.format / console.log function. If an attacker injects a format specifier in the string, it will forge the log message. Try to use constant values for the format string.
cwe: CWE-134: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String
cweId: CWE-134: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String

message: Found '$SPAWN' with '{shell: true}'. This is dangerous because this call will spawn the command using a shell process. Doing so propagates current shell settings and variables, which makes it much easier for a malicious actor to execute commands. Use '{shell: false}' instead.
cwe: CWE-78: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')
cweId: CWE-78: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

message: Detected calls to child_process from a function argument `command`. This could lead to a command injection if the input is user controllable. Try to avoid calls to child_process, and if it is needed ensure user input is correctly sanitized or sandboxed.
cwe: CWE-78: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')
cweId: CWE-78: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')
